articles.headline: Market Swings Are First Crisis for Fed Chairman
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke is under pressure to help bail out investors who bought the risky mortgages that led to the current market panic.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke is under pressure to help bail out investors who bought the risky mortgages that led to the current market panic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Should the Federal Reserve help bail out billionaire hedge fund managers and millionaire traders — the very people who bought the risky mortgages that led to the current market panic?

articles.headline: Central Banks Intervene to Calm Volatile Markets
articles.snippet: Central banks around the world acted in unison to calm investors by injecting tens of billions of dollars into the financial system.
articles.abstract: Central banks around the world acted in unison to calm investors by injecting tens of billions of dollars into the financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: Central banks around the world acted in unison yesterday to calm nervous financial markets by providing an infusion of cash to the system. But stocks still fell sharply in Asia and Europe, and in early trading in New York, before they recovered and closed essentially flat for the day on Wall Street.

articles.headline: States Try to Alter How Presidents Are Elected
articles.snippet: Maneuvers by those upset with the system are adding unpredictability to an already knotty campaign.
articles.abstract: Maneuvers by those upset with the system are adding unpredictability to an already knotty campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 — When state Democratic leaders from around the country meet this weekend in Vermont, the California chairman, Art Torres, expects to be peppered with the sort of questions that have been clogging his in-box for weeks.

articles.headline: Fannie Mae’s Offer to Help Ease Credit Squeeze Is Rejected, as Critics Complain of Opportunism
articles.snippet: The nation’s largest buyer of home loans was blocked Friday by federal regulators from expanding its mortgage holdings.
articles.abstract: The nation’s largest buyer of home loans was blocked Friday by federal regulators from expanding its mortgage holdings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fannie Mae, the nation’s biggest buyer of home loans, was blocked yesterday from expanding its mortgage holdings by 10 percent in what it called an effort to ease concerns about credit and shore up the struggling housing market.

articles.headline: A Segregated Road in an Already Divided Land
articles.snippet: The Israeli side of a divided road being built through the West Bank has various exits; the Palestinian side bypasses Jerusalem.
articles.abstract: The Israeli side of a divided road being built through the West Bank has various exits; the Palestinian side bypasses Jerusalem.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, Aug. 10 — Israel is constructing a road through the West Bank, east of Jerusalem, that will allow both Israelis and Palestinians to travel along it — separately.

articles.headline: Italian Pride Is Revived in a Tiny Fiat
articles.snippet: Fiat has introduced an updated version of the 500, or Cinquecento, the chubby little car that symbolized Italy’s postwar economic miracle.
articles.abstract: Fiat has introduced an updated version of the 500, or Cinquecento, the chubby little car that symbolized Italy’s postwar economic miracle.
articles.lead_paragraph: TURIN, Italy — When Luca De Meo, 40, became chief executive of the Italian carmaker Fiat Automobiles five years ago, one of his relatives — he forgets whether it was his aunt or his mother — told him, “Luca, you’ve got to bring back the 500,” or the Cinquecento, the chubby little car that symbolized Italy’s postwar economic miracle.

articles.headline: Judge Says Unix Copyrights Rightfully Belong to Novell
articles.snippet: A federal judge ruled that Novell, not the SCO Group, is the rightful owner of the copyrights covering the Unix operating system, removing a cloud over open-source software.
articles.abstract: A federal judge ruled that Novell, not the SCO Group, is the rightful owner of the copyrights covering the Unix operating system, removing a cloud over open-source software.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10  In a decision that may finally settle one of the most bitter legal battles surrounding software widely used in corporate data centers, a federal district court judge in Utah ruled Friday afternoon that Novell, not the SCO Group, is the rightful owner of the copyrights covering the Unix operating system.

articles.headline: Far From the Reservation, but Still Sacred?
articles.snippet: In the deserts of the West, developers are increasingly running up against newly powerful but tradition-minded American Indian leaders.
articles.abstract: In the deserts of the West, developers are increasingly running up against newly powerful but tradition-minded American Indian leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yuma, Ariz.

articles.headline: A Week When Risk Came Home to Roost
articles.snippet: For something that everybody assured us was “contained,” the subprime mortgage mess certainly has spread.
articles.abstract: For something that everybody assured us was “contained,” the subprime mortgage mess certainly has spread.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR something that everybody assured us was “contained,” the subprime mortgage mess certainly has spread.

articles.headline: Democrats Say Leaving Iraq May Take Years
articles.snippet: Democratic presidential candidates are setting out positions that could leave the U.S. engaged for years.
articles.abstract: Democratic presidential candidates are setting out positions that could leave the U.S. engaged for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES, Aug. 11 — Even as they call for an end to the war and pledge to bring the troops home, the Democratic presidential candidates are setting out positions that could leave the United States engaged in Iraq for years.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Marc Santora

articles.headline: In a Credit Crisis, Large Mortgages Grow Costly
articles.snippet: Problems in the subprime mortgage market have spread, and the market for big mortgages has dried up.
articles.abstract: Problems in the subprime mortgage market have spread, and the market for big mortgages has dried up.
articles.lead_paragraph: When an investment banker set out to buy a $1.5 million home on Long Island last month, his mortgage broker quoted an interest rate of 8 percent. Three days later, when the buyer said he would take the loan, the mortgage banker had bad news: the new rate was 13 percent.
articles.byline: By Floyd Norris and Eric Dash

articles.headline: China Enacting a High-Tech Plan to Track People
articles.snippet: Security experts describe China’s plans as the world’s largest effort to meld the latest computer technology with police work.
articles.abstract: Security experts describe China’s plans as the world’s largest effort to meld the latest computer technology with police work.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China, Aug. 9 — At least 20,000 police surveillance cameras are being installed along streets here in southern China and will soon be guided by sophisticated computer software from an American-financed company to recognize automatically the faces of police suspects and detect unusual activity.

articles.headline: How a ‘Good War’ in Afghanistan Went Bad
articles.snippet: At key moments in the fight for Afghanistan, the Bush administration diverted scarce resources to Iraq.
articles.abstract: At key moments in the fight for Afghanistan, the Bush administration diverted scarce resources to Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years after the Taliban fell to an American-led coalition, a group of NATO ambassadors landed in Kabul, Afghanistan, to survey what appeared to be a triumph — a fresh start for a country ripped apart by years of war with the Soviets and brutal repression by religious extremists.
articles.byline: By David Rohde and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Suddenly, the Hunt Is On for Cage-Free Eggs
articles.snippet: A rush on the eggs has led to headaches as big buyers learn there may not be enough to go around.
articles.abstract: A rush on the eggs has led to headaches as big buyers learn there may not be enough to go around.
articles.lead_paragraph: The toy industry had its Tickle Me Elmo, the automakers the Prius and technology its iPhone. Now, the food world has its latest have-to-have-it product: the cage-free egg.

articles.headline: When Arbitrators Are Their Own Judges
articles.snippet: For investor advocates, the potential for conflicts of interest among the members of arbitration panels ranks high on the list of problems.
articles.abstract: For investor advocates, the potential for conflicts of interest among the members of arbitration panels ranks high on the list of problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Harley C. McDonald, a retired lawyer for a Nebraska construction company, lost 80 percent of his $60 million stock market nest egg, he lost faith in the brokerage industry.

articles.headline: China, Filling a Void, Drills for Riches in Chad
articles.snippet: Chinese companies are investing heavily in impoverished African countries like Chad, raising Western concerns.
articles.abstract: Chinese companies are investing heavily in impoverished African countries like Chad, raising Western concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: KOUDJIWAI, Chad — The small plane flew in low over a scorched, peppercorn scrubland, following a broad, muddy river that was all elbows on its run to the southeast.
articles.byline: By Howard W. French and Lydia Polgreen

articles.headline: Importing Chiefs, Detroit Reflects on Its ‘Car Guys’
articles.snippet: As a former Home Depot chief heads Chrysler, Detroit has completed a new-model changeover of the executive suite.
articles.abstract: As a former Home Depot chief heads Chrysler, Detroit has completed a new-model changeover of the executive suite.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Aug. 12 — Where have all the car guys gone?

articles.headline: For a Joke-Telling Candidate, a Second-Place Finish
articles.snippet: Mike Huckabee, who placed second in the Iowa Straw Poll, has distinguished himself with his considerable humor.
articles.abstract: Mike Huckabee, who placed second in the Iowa Straw Poll, has distinguished himself with his considerable humor.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES, Aug. 12 — “I can’t buy you — I don’t have the money,” Mike Huckabee, the Arkansas Republican seeking the presidency, told Republicans at the Iowa Straw Poll this weekend. He offered a mock frown.

articles.headline: Pack Mentality Among Hedge Funds Fuels Market Volatility
articles.snippet: As the credit markets have dried up, some quantitative funds could potentially have their worst year on record.
articles.abstract: As the credit markets have dried up, some quantitative funds could potentially have their worst year on record.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, there is a rage against the machine.

articles.headline: Xbox 360 Out of Order? For Loyalists, No Worries
articles.snippet: Owners of the Microsoft Xbox 360 have watched their machines break down. But the game Halo 3 could redeem the company going into the holiday selling season.
articles.abstract: Owners of the Microsoft Xbox 360 have watched their machines break down. But the game Halo 3 could redeem the company going into the holiday selling season.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12— Imagine your blender breaking down twice. The vacuum cleaner giving up the ghost three times. The espresso maker repeatedly going kaput. Then imagine replacing the item with the same model over and over while keeping your brand loyalty and sanity.

articles.headline: Small Investors Seen as Safer in Stock Slide
articles.snippet: The excesses in the financial markets are not in the traditional stocks and bonds where average Americans put their money.
articles.abstract: The excesses in the financial markets are not in the traditional stocks and bonds where average Americans put their money.
articles.lead_paragraph: The wild swings in the stock market over the last few weeks have reawakened memories of the technology crash of 2000 in which many small investors lost their savings. But this time around, market experts say, ordinary investors seem less vulnerable than the professionals who have taken a beating.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Off to Resorts, and Carrying Their Careers
articles.snippet: As technology enables people to work wherever they want, many are clustering in resort playgrounds.
articles.abstract: As technology enables people to work wherever they want, many are clustering in resort playgrounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: STEAMBOAT SPRINGS, Colo. — Time was you could tell the urban refugees in places like this: corporate achievers who quit the rat race to open a bed and breakfast or a candle shoppe.

articles.headline: NBC Making a Clean Start in a House of Mixed Media
articles.snippet: After it bought the Web site iVillage.com last year, NBC Universal bragged that it had landed a digital darling. But few people are boasting about iVillage now.
articles.abstract: After it bought the Web site iVillage.com last year, NBC Universal bragged that it had landed a digital darling. But few people are boasting about iVillage now.
articles.lead_paragraph: After it bought the Web site iVillage.com last year for $600 million, NBC Universal bragged that it had landed a digital darling. The women-focused Internet business was a perfect fit with the “Today” show, executives said, and would turbo-charge their online efforts.

articles.headline: A Variation on the DVR, Without Ad Skipping
articles.snippet: Time Warner Cable is about to offer its customers a free recording feature for their televisions — one that will not allow them to zap through the commercials.
articles.abstract: Time Warner Cable is about to offer its customers a free recording feature for their televisions — one that will not allow them to zap through the commercials.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a move that is certain to delight advertisers, Time Warner Cable is about to offer its customers a free recording feature for their televisions — one that will not allow them to zap through the commercials.
